                                                                                                                                         THE EVOLUTION OF THE EYE.                                      7
                                                                                                                             I   come now to               one of the most recent and
                                                                                                                          curious discoveries          in the history of descent. As
                                                                                                                          every zoologist          knows,       a special       interest attaches

                                                                                                                          Australia, are all examples in point.    Peripatus, a
                                                                                                                          most insigni<U+FB01>cant-looking                  animal       related        to   the

                                                                                                                          observed of all Observers, because it forms a link

                                                                                                                          shell.   The cephalic mantle is the portion of this organ
                                                                                                                          situated near the head of the animal.
                                                                                                                             Composite or Compound Eyes—The large eyes of inSects,
                                                                                                                          made up of a great number of lenses united together, and each

                                                                                                                          formed, part of some living animal or plant). To give some

                                                                                                                           ‘              '
                                                                                                                             broken down by the processes of digestion, respiration, etc.

                                                                                                                          notably the portion known as Peyer’s patches. It is probably
                                                                                                                          caused by a special bacillus, which, through contaminated
                                                                                                                          water or food, <U+FB01>nds its way into the bowel. It is not
                                                                                                                          infectious.                          1
                                                                                                                             Typhns.—A highly contagious fever, now, happily, becom
                                                                                                                          ing rare in England.      It is often known as ‘ famine fever,’ so

                                                                                                                            Vase-motor Nerves.—Nerves which control the arteries,
                                                                                                                          causing constriction or expansion in these vessels. Division of
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          the nerve known as the cervical-sympathetic causes a dilation
                                                                                                                          of the minute arteries of the neck on the same side, whilst a
                                                                                                                          division of the sciatic nerve causes a similar dilation of the
                                                                                                                          small arteries of the foot and legs, and in both cases the
                                                                                                                          thermometer shows a rise in temperature.     Blushing is caused

                                                                                                                             Zoea.—An early stage in the life of decayed crustaceans
                                                                                                                          (lobsters, shrimps, etc.), which is so different to the adult
                                                                                                                          form that it was originally described as a distinct animal.
                                                                                                                             Zoology (Gr. zoon, an animal; logos, a discourse).—The
                                                                                                                          science which treats of animals, in contradistinction to
                                                                                                                          botany, which deals with plants, and biology, which is
                                                                                                                          concerned with both animals and plants.

                                                                                                                          searches show that these diseases are probably caused by
